{{mergeto|Criminal procedure|date=November 2011}} {{globalize/USA|date=February 2010}} {{Criminal procedure (trial)}} The '''rights of the accused''' is a "class" of [[civil and political rights]] that apply to a person accused of a [[crime]], from when he or she is [[arrest]]ed and [[criminal charge|charged]] to when he or she is either [[Conviction (law)|convicted]] or [[Acquittal|acquitted]]. Rights of the accused are generally based on the maxim of "[[presumption of innocence|innocent until proven guilty]]" and are [[due process]].
In the [[United States]], these rights are guaranteed in the [[United States Bill of Rights|Bill of Rights]] (the first ten [[List of amendments to the United States Constitution|amendments to the United States Constitution]]), particularly in the [[Fourth Amendment to the United States Constitution|Fourth]], [[Fifth Amendment to the United States Constitution|Fifth]], [[Sixth Amendment to the United States Constitution|Sixth]], and [[Eighth Amendment to the United States Constitution|Eighth Amendments]].
The rights of the accused sometimes comes into conflict with promotion of [[victims' rights]].
==Limits on the Conduct of Police Officers and Prosecuters== No unreasonable or unwarranted searches No arrest except on probable cause No coerced confessions or illegal interrogation No Entrapment On questioning, a suspect must be informed of his or her rights.
==Defendent's Pretrial Rights== Writ of habeaus corpus Prompt arraignment Legal Counsel Reasonable Bail To Remain Silent
==Trial Rights== Speedy and public trial before a jury Impartial jury selected from a cross section of community No compulsory self-incrimination Adequate counsel No Cruel and unusual punishment Appeal of convictions No double Jeopardy <ref>{{cite book|last=Bardes|first=Barbara|title=American Government and Politics today}}</ref>
